Award.AwardTitle: Southeastern Atlantic Regional Conference on Differential Equations 2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports participation in the thirty-fifth annual meeting of the Southeastern Atlantic Regional Conference on Differential Equations (SEARCDE), on October 10-11, 2015, at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro. The conference began in 1981 and has met annually since then, with the venue rotating among research institutions in the Southeast. The conference continues SEARCDE's tradition as a forum for discussion and exchange of research ideas and recent developments in both theoretical and applied differential equations. In addition to four invited plenary lectures by leading international scholars in differential equations, there are twenty-minute contributed talks given in parallel sessions. All participants have the opportunity to present their work in these contributed talks, which are organized so that talks by established and senior researchers are interspersed with talks by beginning researchers. Information about the conference can be found at the website, http://www.uncg.edu/mat/searcdeconf/2015 .

The principal objective of the SEARCDE conference is to promote research and education in the field of differential equations by bringing together established and beginning researchers to exchange ideas and discuss recent developments. The conference tradition fosters an atmosphere conducive to networking and the creation of new research collaborations. SEARCDE especially encourages the participation of beginning researchers, who get the opportunity to meet and hear renowned plenary speakers and senior researchers from the region. For over three decades SEARCDE has been the setting for many graduate students to deliver their first conference lectures. For others it has been their first opportunity to discuss their research with senior research faculty outside their graduate institution. Many researchers continue to participate regularly in the SEARCDE conference throughout their careers. The conference series provides important opportunities for young researchers, especially those from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of the annual Southeastern Atlantic Regional Conference on Differential Equations (SEARCDE)
is to bring together senior and junior researchers, ranging from new graduate students to established professors,
to exchange research ideas in the broad field of applied mathematics known as differential equations. The two day
conference format includes four featured plenary lectures by internationally recognized leading researchers in
differential equations, as well as parallel sessions of shorter lectures. The hour-long plenary lectures are attended
by all conference participants, and the parallel sessions are structured so that each session includes talks by both
established and beginning researchers. This structure fosters opportunities for beginning researchers to make new
connections, to receive feedback on their work from more senior colleagues, and to begin possible research
collaborations. The featured plenary lectures provide all attendees the opportunity to become aware of the latest
research ideas and open problems in differential equations. This annual conference has gained a reputation for
encouraging new, young researchers, and for fostering an atmosphere of serious science and friendly exchange of ideas.

The 35th SEARCDE conference was held October 10-11, 2015, in the Sullivan Science Building on the campus of the
University of North Carolina at Greensboro. The featured plenary speakers were H.T. `Tom' Banks (North Carolina
State University), Pavel Drabek (University of West Bohemia, Czech Republic), Lisa Fauci (Tulane University), and
Peter Polacik (University of Minnesota). All four plenary lectures were excellent and informative, and all four
speakers gave generously of their time in speaking with other conference participants, especially junior researchers.

There were a total of 128 registered paid attendees, and 95 talks in the parallel sessions. The NSF funds provided
support to 42 young researchers, which included 23 graduate students and 19 recent PhD recipients.
